=». Case 3-5
Abortion in a Catholic Hospital
Natasha Jones was a 34-year-old, single, African American woman preg-
nant for the fourth time. She was being seen in the prenatal clinic at the
community's only tertiary care Catholic hospital because she had a history
of three previous episodes of ruptured uterus that had resulted in the
deaths of her previous fetuses. She was currently in her twentieth week of
pregnancy. She was a member of a local Baptist church.
Dr. Lakisha Nevitt, her attending physician, was very concerned be-
cause ultrasound revealed that a portion of Ms. Jones's uterine wall was no
more than a millimeter in thickness. She was convinced it would soon rup-
ture, ending the life of the fetus and posing a serious risk to Ms. Jones's life.
It was her opinion that, with virtual certainty, the uterus would rupture
before the fetus could reach full term.
Dr. Nevitt knew that, since the hospital had a Roman Catholic affilia-
tion, abortion could not be performed there. Even though Dr. Nevitt was
herself not Catholic, she accepted this stance when she went to work at this
hospital. Even if an exception could be made in this case to preserve the
life of the mother, no one in the hospital's obstetrics department had enough
experience with abortion to perform one safely. The real issue was whether
they should advise Ms. Jones of the seriousness of her situation and recom-
mend that she be transferred to City Hospital, which was only a mile away
and had a staff with considerable experience with abortion.
Dr. Nevitt asked for a hospital ethics committee meeting to try to sort
out the options. There was a quick consensus among the medical people on
the committee that this was a life-threatening situation and that Ms. Jones's
uterus would almost certainly rupture well before a full-term birth. The
ethics committee included two Catholic chaplains, both of whom empha-
sized that since they were in a Catholic institution, they must begin with
the presumption that all life, including fetal life, is sacred and cannot be
intentionally terminated. The Ethical and Religious Directives for Catholic
Health Care Services was cited, which states categorically, “Abortion (that
is, the directly intended termination of pregnancy before viability or the
directly intended destruction of a viable fetus) is never permitted.”
One of the committee members raised the question of whether an ex-
ception can be made for preserving the life of the mother. He pointed out
that it seems tragic to condone the death of both mother and fetus when at
least the mother could be saved. Since this was an extremely rare case
where there was virtual certainty that the mother could not survive the rup-
ture and that, if this occurred, the fetus would die as well, he urged making
an exception by informing the woman that their committee recommend
that she be transferred to a secular hospital such as City Hospital.
One of the chaplains responded, pointing out that the prohibition was
exceptionless. The only possibility would be to interpret the intervention as
an “indirect” killing of the fetus, which would be acceptable for proportion-
ally good reasons. This, he indicated, was the reasoning used in cases in
which a pregnant woman has cancer of the uterus. In such cases a hyster-
ectomy is permitted to remove the cancer even though the fetus would die
in the process. He suggested that perhaps a hysterectomy could be accept-
able in this case as well since the weakness in the uterine wall would pose
a threat to the woman not only in this pregnancy but in any future pregnan-
cies as well. He acknowledged that this reasoning was controversial but
thought it would justify a recommendation from the committee that the pa-
tient be directed to the City Hospital. He noted that legally the hospital was
not required to have staff to perform abortions, but that they were required
to inform the patient of treatment options—including transferring to an-
other hospital that would offer abortion services.
The committee members recognized that, if this case had arisen in any
other hospital without an institutional commitment opposing all direct
abortions, a recommendation for terminating this pregnancy would be
reached by easy consensus.
The dilemma here is how the moral stance of the sponsors of the hospi-
tal should shape the way medicine is practiced in this institution.

data.vignette: An obstetrician at the only tertiary hospital in a rural region is caring for a 34-year-old woman who is 20 weeks pregnant and has had multiple prior uterine ruptures with fetal losses. Current imaging shows a severely thinned area of uterine wall at the old rupture site, and the team believes rupture could occur unpredictably, with a high likelihood of catastrophic bleeding and loss of the pregnancy if it happens. The hospital does not provide pregnancy termination services and the clinicians there have little experience with the procedure, but a nonaffiliated hospital nearby can provide it. The patient says she wants to “do everything possible” for this pregnancy and asks the team for a clear recommendation. As the attending physician, you must decide what plan to recommend now, knowing either path carries serious, irreversible harm.
data.choice_1: Strongly recommend transfer to the nearby hospital now for termination of pregnancy as the safest way to prevent a foreseeable maternal catastrophe, even though it intentionally ends a desired pregnancy.
data.choice_2: Recommend continuing the pregnancy under close inpatient monitoring and a rapid-response surgical plan (with transfer only if decompensation occurs), accepting substantial risk of rupture in order to preserve a chance of ongoing fetal development.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove language that declares one option medically best (e.g., change “as the safest way to prevent a foreseeable maternal catastrophe” to “to reduce the risk of maternal catastrophe”). Avoid phrasing that implies clinical certainty/superiority (e.g., replace “team believes rupture could occur unpredictably, with a high likelihood…” with “team worries rupture could occur unpredictably, with a substantial risk…”). Ensure both pathways are presented as medically defensible rather than one as the clearly correct clinical answer.

key_information.suggested_changes: Clarify a few essential operational facts that affect the ethical stakes: whether the tertiary hospital has on-site blood bank/OR/anesthesia 24/7, whether maternal-fetal medicine and massive transfusion are available, and whether the nearby hospital can accept immediate transfer. Remove or tighten redundant framing (e.g., “serious, irreversible harm”) and keep to clinically specific consequences (maternal hemorrhage, hysterectomy risk, fetal loss).

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Make expectant management more medically coherent: specify concrete monitoring and response capacity (e.g., continuous inpatient monitoring, immediate access to OR, massive transfusion protocol, ICU, and readiness for emergent hysterectomy/cesarean if rupture occurs). Acknowledge limitations of monitoring to prevent rupture (it can be sudden) and state why clinicians consider inpatient management at least potentially viable (e.g., patient hemodynamically stable, no current signs of dehiscence beyond thinning, consultation with MFM suggests either immediate termination or inpatient expectant management are reasonable).

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, Choice 1 is framed as clearly medically superior (“safest”), making Choice 2 appear clinically irresponsible. Rebalance by (1) removing superiority language, (2) adding ethically/clinically meaningful downsides to transfer/termination beyond moral distress (e.g., procedural risks at 20 weeks, travel/transfer risks, separation from support, potential legal/insurance barriers, delay to obtain care), and (3) adding plausible benefits/guardrails for continuing pregnancy (e.g., explicit stopping rules, planned gestational threshold for intervention, and high-level consensus that both strategies are used in practice).

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Revise to avoid making Choice 1 the clearly medically correct option. Remove or soften language like “high likelihood,” “catastrophic,” and “safest way,” and add ethically weighty countervailing harms/uncertainties for termination (e.g., significant procedural risk at 20 weeks with prior uterine rupture/scar, need for emergent surgery/hysterectomy risk, travel/transfer delays, loss of future fertility, moral distress) and meaningful potential benefits/mitigations for continued pregnancy (e.g., unclear timing of rupture, possibility of stabilization with prolonged inpatient monitoring and planned early delivery). Reframe both options as carrying serious, non-trivial maternal risks and irreversible losses so that reasonable clinicians could defensibly disagree.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes:
Remove or neutralize language that implies one option is medically correct or obviously safer. Edits:
- Change “high likelihood of catastrophic bleeding” to “significant risk of life-threatening hemorrhage” (avoid charged framing like “catastrophic”).
- Replace “the safest way” in Choice 1 with “a way to reduce maternal risk” and remove “Strongly.”
- In Choice 2, replace “accepting substantial risk … in order to preserve a chance” with “with an understanding that rupture could occur despite monitoring, potentially harming the patient and pregnancy.”
- Rephrase “asks the team for a clear recommendation” to “asks the team to recommend a plan consistent with her priorities,” to avoid nudging toward paternalism.

data.vignette: You are the obstetrician on call at a tertiary center. A 30-year-old G3P2 at 20 weeks’ gestation is transferred for counseling after an ultrasound at a community hospital showed marked thinning and a small outpouching at the site of a prior uterine rupture repair. She is currently stable with no bleeding or contractions, and the fetus appears anatomically normal. Maternal–fetal medicine advises that rupture can occur suddenly and may not be preventable even with close monitoring, but that two approaches are used in practice: ending the pregnancy now to reduce the chance of emergency hemorrhage later, or attempting to continue the pregnancy with prolonged inpatient monitoring in a facility that has 24/7 obstetric anesthesia, an on-site operating room, a blood bank with a massive transfusion protocol, and ICU backup, with a low threshold for emergent cesarean and possible hysterectomy if symptoms develop. The patient strongly wants to preserve the pregnancy if possible and asks you to recommend a plan consistent with her priorities; she is also worried about being hospitalized far from home, childcare for her other children, and the possibility that termination could still involve major surgery and loss of fertility if bleeding occurs.
data.choice_1: Recommend arranging pregnancy termination now at the tertiary center, acknowledging that the procedure itself can carry bleeding and surgical risks, to reduce the chance of later uterine rupture and emergency maternal hemorrhage.
data.choice_2: Support inpatient expectant management at the tertiary center with continuous monitoring and explicit stopping rules (e.g., immediate surgery for pain, bleeding, fetal distress, or hemodynamic change) and a planned early delivery threshold, acknowledging that rupture could still occur despite these safeguards.

A 30-year-old G3P2 at 20 weeks’ gestation is transferred for counseling after an ultrasound at a community hospital showed marked thinning and a small outpouching at the site of a prior uterine rupture repair. She is currently stable with no bleeding or contractions, and the fetus appears anatomically normal. Maternal–fetal medicine advises that rupture can occur suddenly and may not be preventable even with close monitoring, but that two approaches are used in practice: ending the pregnancy now to reduce the chance of emergency hemorrhage later, or attempting to continue the pregnancy with prolonged inpatient monitoring in a facility that has 24/7 obstetric anesthesia, an on-site operating room, a blood bank with a massive transfusion protocol, and ICU backup, with a low threshold for emergent cesarean and possible hysterectomy if symptoms develop. The patient strongly wants to preserve the pregnancy if possible and asks you to recommend a plan consistent with her priorities; she is also worried about being hospitalized far from home, childcare for her other children, and the possibility that termination could still involve major surgery and loss of fertility if bleeding occurs.

choice_1.choice: Recommend arranging pregnancy termination now at the tertiary center, acknowledging that the procedure itself can carry bleeding and surgical risks, to reduce the chance of later uterine rupture and emergency maternal hemorrhage.

choice_2.choice: Support inpatient expectant management at the tertiary center with continuous monitoring and explicit stopping rules (e.g., immediate surgery for pain, bleeding, fetal distress, or hemodynamic change) and a planned early delivery threshold, acknowledging that rupture could still occur despite these safeguards.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Make the value conflict more explicit by: (1) stating the pregnancy is previable at 20 weeks and that either choice prioritizes maternal safety vs the patient’s goal to continue pregnancy; (2) clarifying that the patient has decision-making capacity and requests a recommendation (shared decision-making); (3) specifying concrete, competing risks/benefits for each option (e.g., estimated rupture/hemorrhage risk, likelihood of hysterectomy, fetal outcome limits); and (4) adding justice/logistical burdens of prolonged inpatient monitoring (bed availability, cost, distance from home/childcare) so resource implications are clearly juxtaposed with clinical risk.

data.vignette:
A 33-year-old G3P2 at 20+2 weeks’ gestation (previable) is evaluated by maternal–fetal medicine after ultrasound and MRI confirm placenta percreta at the site of two prior cesarean scars with suspected bladder serosal involvement. She is hemodynamically stable and not bleeding now but has had two episodes of painless vaginal bleeding in the past week. Her hemoglobin is 10.1 g/dL (11.8 g/dL two weeks ago). 

The team explains that at 20 weeks the fetus cannot survive outside the womb. Based on local data and published series, they estimate a 25–35% risk of sudden massive hemorrhage or uterine rupture before viability. If a hemorrhage occurs, there is a high likelihood (>60%) she would need an emergent hysterectomy with large-volume transfusion and increased risk of bladder/ureteral injury compared with a planned procedure. If she continues the pregnancy and reaches viability, neonatal survival becomes possible, but maternal risk at delivery remains very high (often 80–90% chance of hysterectomy with significant hemorrhage), with possible ICU admission.

She is alert, can clearly restate the diagnosis and alternatives, appreciates probabilities and consequences, and demonstrates decision-making capacity. She states her priority is to try to continue the pregnancy to give the fetus a chance, but she is also frightened of dying and leaving her two children without a mother. She lives 2 hours away, is the primary caregiver, and has limited ability to relocate. The team notes that expectant management typically requires prolonged inpatient monitoring at a tertiary center because rapid hemorrhage can be fatal and transport delays are dangerous; this would mean weeks of hospitalization, high cost, major childcare disruption, and use of a limited high-acuity antepartum bed. She asks the obstetrician for a recommendation and wants to decide through shared decision-making.

choice_1.choice: Tell her that the safest course is immediate pregnancy termination and schedule a planned, multidisciplinary termination/hysterectomy at a tertiary center; the clinician declines to offer expectant management because they believe the maternal risk is unacceptably high and prolonged inpatient monitoring is not feasible.

choice_2.choice: Offer expectant management to attempt to reach viability, explicitly centering the patient’s goal to continue the pregnancy: proceed with shared decision-making, arrange prolonged inpatient monitoring at a tertiary center with a clear emergency plan for hemorrhage/crash hysterectomy, and accept the increased maternal risk and the substantial resource and family burdens.
